column1: Type 2 diabetes is a chronic (lifelong) disease.
Insulin is a hormone made by the pancreas to control blood sugar.
When your body's insulin is not used correctly, the sugar from food stays in the blood and the level can get too high.
Foods with sugar and carbohydrates can raise your blood sugar too high.
Alcohol and other drinks with sugar can also raise your blood sugar.
Weight-loss surgery may be an option if you are obese (very overweight) and your diabetes is not under control.
Regular exercise is good for people with diabetes.
In case of an emergency, people know you have diabetes and can help you get the right medical attention.
Many people with type 2 diabetes need to take more than one medicine to control their blood sugar.
If medicines do not help you control your blood sugar, you may need to take insulin.
- Your doctor may ask you to take a medicine called an ACE inhibitor or another medicine called an ARB for high blood pressure or kidney problems.
- Your doctor may ask you to take a special medicine called a statin to keep your cholesterol low.
- Your doctor may ask you to take aspirin to keep your heart healthy.
